questions.question: What is the area, in square units, of a rectangle with a length of <math><mn>9</mn></math> units and a width of <math><mn>6</mn></math> units?
questions.explanation: The area of a rectangle is <math><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math>. Substituting <math><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> and <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> gives <math><mn>9</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>54</mn></math> square units.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the formula for rectangle area: length × width. Avoid confusing it with perimeter.

questions.question: The area of a square is <math><mn>144</mn></math> square centimeters. What is its side length, in centimeters?
questions.explanation: If <math><mi>s</mi></math> is the side length, then <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>144</mn></math>. Taking the positive square root gives <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> cm.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For squares, side length is the square root of the area. Don’t confuse with perimeter, which is 4 times the side length.

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>27</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 8 to both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>35</mn></math>. Divide by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation.

questions.question: A store increases the price of an item from <math><mn>40</mn></math> dollars to <math><mn>50</mn></math> dollars. By what percent did the price increase?
questions.explanation: The increase is <math><mn>50</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> dollars. Percent increase = <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Percent change = (change / original) × 100%. Pay attention to which value is the original.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is graphed in the xy-plane. What are the x-coordinates of its x-intercepts?
questions.explanation: The x-intercepts occur where <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Thus, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic in factored form, set each factor equal to zero to find the x-intercepts.

questions.question: A cube has a volume of <math><mn>343</mn></math> cubic centimeters. What is the surface area, in square centimeters, of the cube?
questions.explanation: Volume = <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>343</mn></math>, so side length <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> cm. Surface area = <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>49</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>294</mn><msup><mi> cm</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a cube: Volume = <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>, Surface Area = <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Work step-by-step.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Adding the two equations eliminates <math><mi>y</mi></math>: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving systems, look for the easiest elimination or substitution method. Adding equations can quickly eliminate a variable.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><polygon points='60,50 60,150 240,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='60,140 70,140 70,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='40' y='165' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='245' y='165' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='40' y='45' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='150' y='170' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='160' y='95' font-size='14'>13</text><text x='40' y='105' font-size='14'>x</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle ABC with the right angle at vertex B. The vertical side AB is labeled x, the horizontal side BC is labeled 12, and the diagonal hypotenuse AC is labeled 13.
questions.question: In right triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math> is the right angle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>. What is the length of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: By the Pythagorean Theorem: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math> implies <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>13</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Solving for x: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>169</mn></math> which leads to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><polygon points='60,50 60,150 240,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='60,140 70,140 70,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='40' y='165' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='245' y='165' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='40' y='45' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='150' y='170' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='160' y='95' font-size='14'>13</text><text x='40' y='105' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>5</text><text x='130' y='50' font-size='12' fill='red'>AB² + BC² = AC²</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Right triangle with the solution x=5 labeled in red. The Pythagorean equation is displayed.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Know the Pythagorean Theorem: a² + b² = c², where c is the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle).

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='370' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='50' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='210' y='240' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>Score Range</text><text x='30' y='115' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90,30,115)' text-anchor='middle'>Frequency</text><rect x='70' y='160' width='40' height='40' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='130' y='120' width='40' height='80' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='190' y='100' width='40' height='100' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='250' y='60' width='40' height='140' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='310' y='140' width='40' height='60' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><text x='90' y='155' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><text x='150' y='115' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>4</text><text x='210' y='95' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='270' y='55' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>7</text><text x='330' y='135' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>3</text><text x='90' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>60-69</text><text x='150' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>70-79</text><text x='210' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>80-89</text><text x='270' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>90-99</text><text x='330' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>100-109</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Histogram showing frequency distribution of test scores. The x-axis represents score ranges and the y-axis represents frequency. The bar heights correspond to the following data: 60-69: 2, 70-79: 4, 80-89: 5, 90-99: 7, 100-109: 3.
questions.question: The histogram shows the distribution of test scores for a class. How many students scored below <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>80</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Scores below <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>80</mn></math> are contained in the intervals <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn><mtext>-</mtext><mn>69</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>70</mn><mtext>-</mtext><mn>79</mn></math>. The frequencies for these intervals are <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn></math>, respectively. Calculating the total: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> students.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='370' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='50' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='210' y='240' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>Score Range</text><text x='30' y='115' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90,30,115)' text-anchor='middle'>Frequency</text><rect x='70' y='160' width='40' height='40' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='130' y='120' width='40' height='80' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='190' y='100' width='40' height='100' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='250' y='60' width='40' height='140' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><rect x='310' y='140' width='40' height='60' fill='lightgray' stroke='black'/><text x='90' y='155' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><text x='150' y='115' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>4</text><text x='210' y='95' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='270' y='55' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>7</text><text x='330' y='135' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>3</text><text x='90' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>60-69</text><text x='150' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>70-79</text><text x='210' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>80-89</text><text x='270' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>90-99</text><text x='330' y='215' font-size='10' text-anchor='middle'>100-109</text><text x='250' y='30' font-size='14' fill='blue' text-anchor='middle'>Scores < 80: 2 + 4 = 6</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Histogram with the first two bars (intervals 60-69 and 70-79) highlighted in light blue to indicate the sum of their frequencies.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Read histograms carefully. Identify which bars correspond to the condition (e.g., 'below 80') and sum their frequencies.

questions.question: If <math><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math> and <math><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi></math> in terms of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: <math><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>17</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Substitute carefully and distribute negatives correctly when simplifying expressions.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>g</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, where <math><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant. The minimum value of <math><mi>g</mi></math> is <math><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a quadratic <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, the vertex (minimum when a>0) occurs at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>. Here, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Substitute into g: <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Set equal to −5: <math><mi>k</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math> → <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The vertex of a parabola given by ax² + bx + c is at x = -b/(2a). Use it to find the minimum/maximum value.

questions.question: A sphere of radius <math><mn>6</mn></math> is inscribed inside a cube so that it touches all six faces of the cube. What is the volume of the cube?
questions.explanation: If the sphere touches all faces, its diameter equals the cube's edge length. Diameter = <math><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Edge length of cube = <math><mn>12</mn></math>. Volume = <math><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1728</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Visualize the relationship: for a sphere inscribed in a cube, the sphere's diameter equals the cube's side length.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math> and <math><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: From the second equation, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>26</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math> → <math><mn>13</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>39</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Thus, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving systems, sometimes you can find a combination of equations that gives the desired expression directly, without solving for each variable individually.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor numerator and denominator: <math><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>. Cancel <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math> (since <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>) to get <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Factor polynomials completely before canceling common factors in rational expressions.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='160' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='350' y1='200' x2='160' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='50' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='215' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='355' y='215' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='195' y='220' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>D</text><text x='155' y='40' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><path d='M190 200 A 30 30 0 0 0 176 178' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='150' y='190' font-size='12'>72°</text><path d='M210 200 A 30 30 0 0 1 205 173' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='220' y='190' font-size='12'>x°</text><text x='155' y='80' font-size='12'>y°</text><line x1='125' y1='195' x2='125' y2='205' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='275' y1='195' x2='275' y2='205' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with point D on the base AC. Line segment BD connects vertex B to D. The segments AD and DC are marked as equal. Angle ADB is labeled 72°, angle BDC is labeled x°, and angle ABD is labeled y°.
questions.question: In the figure, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. The measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>72</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Angles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> are a linear pair because they lie on the straight line <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. Therefore, they sum to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. We calculate <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>72</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>108</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='160' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='350' y1='200' x2='160' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='50' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='215' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='355' y='215' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='195' y='220' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>D</text><text x='155' y='40' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><path d='M170 200 A 30 30 0 1 1 230 200' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><text x='150' y='190' font-size='12'>72°</text><text x='220' y='190' font-size='12' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>108°</text><line x1='125' y1='195' x2='125' y2='205' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='275' y1='195' x2='275' y2='205' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The previous triangle with the straight angle at D highlighted in blue, showing that the two angles sum to 180 degrees. The solution 108 is shown in red.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for linear pairs: Angles that form a straight line always add up to 180°.

questions.question: A bag contains 4 red marbles and 6 blue marbles. Two marbles are drawn at random without replacement. What is the probability that both marbles are red?
questions.explanation: Probability first is red: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac></math>. Given that, probability second is red: <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>. Multiply: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>90</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'without replacement' probability, adjust the probability for the second draw based on the outcome of the first.

questions.question: What is the sum of the solutions to the equation <math><mo>|</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Case 1: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Case 2: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Sum = <math><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For absolute value equations, consider both positive and negative cases of the expression inside the absolute value.

questions.question: A right circular cone has a height of 12 and a base radius of 5. What is the volume of the cone?
questions.explanation: Volume of a cone = <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. Substituting <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>: <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the volume formulas for common solids: cone = (1/3)πr²h, cylinder = πr²h, sphere = (4/3)πr³.

questions.question: Which of the following represents all values of <math><mi>x</mi></math> that satisfy the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math> → subtract 3x: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math> → subtract 8: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math> → divide by 2: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi></math>, or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving inequalities, treat them like equations, but remember to flip the inequality sign if you multiply or divide by a negative number.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 100,100 Q 200,300 300,100' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='3'/><text x='350' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>x</text><text x='190' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>y</text><text x='100' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>-2</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>-1</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>0</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>1</text><text x='300' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><circle cx='150' cy='175' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='250' cy='175' r='5' fill='red'/><text x='185' y='205' font-size='10' text-anchor='end'>100</text><text x='185' y='180' font-size='10' text-anchor='end'>150</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Graph of a parabola opening upward with its vertex on the y-axis at (0, 100). The curve passes through the marked points (-1, 150) and (1, 150).
questions.question: The graph of the quadratic function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math> is a parabola that passes through the points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Which of the following could be the vertex of the parabola?
questions.explanation: Since the parabola is symmetric and passes through <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, the axis of symmetry is the vertical line halfway between <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, which is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The vertex lies on this axis, so its x-coordinate is 0. Only options B and D have <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Since the y-values at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>1</mn></math> are 150 and the vertex is the minimum point (parabola opens upward), the vertex y-value must be less than 150. Thus, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is correct.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 100,100 Q 200,300 300,100' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='3'/><text x='350' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>x</text><text x='190' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>y</text><text x='100' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>-2</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>-1</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>0</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>1</text><text x='300' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><circle cx='150' cy='175' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='250' cy='175' r='5' fill='red'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><circle cx='200' cy='200' r='6' fill='green' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='215' y='205' font-size='14' fill='green' font-weight='bold'>Vertex (0,100)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The parabola is shown with its axis of symmetry at x=0 (dashed green line). The vertex is highlighted in green at the minimum point (0,100), which lies equidistant from the two red points at y=150.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use symmetry: if a parabola passes through two points with the same y-coordinate, the axis of symmetry is exactly halfway between their x-coordinates.
